cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Naxon November 4 from Antwerp.
S.S. Tinos November 5 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Delos 24th from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.
N. SPATHIS, Agent.
CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE JAPANESE PERIL.
div.p: The writer of the “chronique” on foreign affairs inthe “Fortnightly Review” takes a very serious view of the inflax ot Japanese.into British Columbia and California. While con lemning the unprovoked attacker upon the Japanese, he points out that the attempt of white labour to stem the yellow flood is a mere inevitable expression of the instinct of self. preservation.

Japanese immigration must either be restrict ed or unrestricted, he says. The former course means serious diplomatic difficulty at Tokio. The latter coarse means an absolutely fatal feud with Australian and Canadian democracy. If Japanese immigration is not restricted the Japanese will be in great majority in British Columbia in leas than a decade. British white labour would be simply submerged by the yellow flood :—

The colony might remain for a time under the British flag, bat would ultimately cease to be in any sense a British colony. In the long ran there would be a racial war, and either British Columbia would become part of the United States, or the Japanesewould maintain their footing upon the Pacific slope under their own flag.
It is absolutely certain that with unrestrict ed immigration California in twenty years would be a Japanese State, inhabited by « white minority :-—

The unrestricted influx of yellow immigrants would create along the Pacific strip of North America an Asiatic Chili. The conditions of the whole American problem would be gradu- ally but funadmentally transformed. The most destractive of all imaginable solvents would be applied to the Monroe doctrine. Asiatics would hold both sides of the Pacific, as Buropeans hold both sides of the Atlantic, and all civilisation might be dominated or convalsed for centaries hy that state of things, as the Middle Ages were moved and vitalised by the secalar conflict between Christendom and Islam.

Summing up, he concludes that for all pur poses of this generation the dangers of an norestricted Asiatic invasion are too great. It will not be allowed. He fully admits the diffi culty of inducing the Japanese to accept a position of inequality internationally equivilant to the medieval status of the Jews : —

The Japanese have, perhaps, yet to realise, as their acquaintance with the West becomes more familiar and their knowledge of it more subtle, that all Earopean political arrange ments, except where the direct issue is war, are based upon illogical but convenient com promise must be the foundation of any tempor ary settlement.
Some middle course mast be found, for :—

Atsolate exclusion of the yellow race from all the enormous anfilled territories claimed as white man's country would mean war. Bat the unrestricted invasion would lead even more certainly to war in a worse form. No one is justified in taking an optimistic view of this question.
A truly unpleasant dilemma likely to tax the patience and wisdom of statesmen for many a year to come.

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: The Quatantine Board have decided to apply’ in Egyptian Ports plague regulations against arrivals from Mytelene.

div.head: Press Libel Case.
div.p: The appeal of Dr. Sarrouf, of “Al Mokattam,” against the jadgment passed during his absence has been accepted and the sentence repealed.

div.head: British Engineering Company.
div.p: The head office of the British Engineering Company of Egypt, Ltd., has been transferred to No, 10. Sharia Zervadachi, Cairo.

div.head: Official Salaries.
div.p: Economy is the order of the day in the Egyptian Government service at the present time, and the increases of salaries this year are very unlikely to be numerous.

div.head: Ports and Lighthouses Administration.
div.p: The tender stbmitted by Mr. Gripari for the construction of a “Magasin en béton armé” on Quay M. at Alexandria has been accepted.

div.head: Public Works Ministry
div.p: The adjudication for the construction of offices, ete., for the Irrigation Service engineers at Tantah has been approved in favour of Measrs. Rossetto and Dnmont for the sum of LE. 1,942.

div.head: Luxor Industrial Sohool.
div.p: Mohamed Ali Bey Sharara, Mondir of Ke- neh has formed a committee ander the pre- sidency of Ayoub Bey Sabry to collect sub- scriptions for creating an indostrial school at Luxor

div.head: Egyptian Religion.
div.p: The scholarly work of Adolph Erman on the religion of the old Egyptians has recently been translated by Mr. A. S. Griffiths from the German and is annoanced for pnblication. It is abook ot deep charm written by one who is an authority on the subject.

div.head: Egypt and Recent Discoveries.
div.p: The society for promoting christian know- ledge, has just published an interesting work entitled “Egypt and Western Asia in the Light of Recent Discoveries.” The authors are L.W. King, M.A., FS.A., and R.H. Hall, M.A., of the British Museum.

div.head: Gum Arable.
div.p: Mr. C.A. Greig, the British Vice-Consul at Alexandria bas forwarded to London samples’ of six difterent varieties of gum arabic, together with particulars as to prices c.if. to any port in Rurope The samples may be inspécted by British firms at the Commercial Intelligence’ Branch of the Board of Trade, 73, Basinghall Street, E.C

div.head: Damage to Nile Steamer.
div.p: Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son's magnificent new steamer the “Egypt,” sustained some slight damage when making a preliminary trip, at Ambaba. Owing to some gyassas blocking the way she got jammed and her paddle boxes were damaged ; fortunately how ever to no serions extent.

div.head: Interesting Discovery.
div.p: One of the most interesting of recent disco- veries in Egypt is a huge marble head of Juno, its face absolutely uninjared, which was found near Hawara in the oasis of the Fayoum. It is almost certainly of the early Roman period, as there are abundant traces of Greek influence. The head was obviously made separately and fitted on to the colossal statue after the latter was erected ; it is 17 in. from the base ot the neck to the crown of the head, and 12 im. wide at tho brow. It is one of the most beautiful Roman heads that has yet been discovered in Egypt

div.head: The Hational Hotel.
div.p: The National Hotel, which has been subject ed to many alterations and improvements during the past sammer is to be re-opened on Nov. 1st under the new management of Mr. P. E. Hergel, who has just returned from a most successful season at the Grand Hotel, Deanville The new manager, who has bronght his own staff from Europe, is thoroughly conversant with the necessities of hotel life in Egypt having acted for the past four seasons as manager of the Tewfik Palace Hotel Helouan The addition of a large American bar is one of the more prominent changes which have been made in the National Hotel since last season.

div.head: Beau Rivage Hotel.
div.p: Our residential readers will be glad to learn that the popular Beau Rivage Hotel, Ramleh, onder the i ip and able managershi)» of Messrs. G. and M. Runkewitz is to remain open throughout the winter season. l'or several years this hotel bas held a foremost place among the hostelries of Ramleh, and it well sustains the-popularity which it gained during the earlier years of its existence. When taken over by the Runkewitz Brothers every possible improvement was effected and the hotel now boasts the finest garden in Alexandria, a cuisine which cannot be excelled, and a general instal- ment equal to any hotel in Egypt. The service of the hotel is all that could be desired, its bedrooms are not only airy but also luxuriously farnished, and private suites can be arranged for by order in advace. In the Beau Rivage the tourist will find every home com fort at the most moderate terms, and with every facility for connection with Alexandria. Messrs. G. and M. Runkewitz have now been recognised for several years as among the leading hotel proprietors of Egypt, and from among the many British clients of note for whom they have catered they have in- variatly received congratulations upon the excellent - manner in which their hotels of Ramleh and Luxor were conducted. In conclnsion we might remark that the winter terms will be placed at a lower tarif than those of the summer months, the service at the same time remaining unchanged.

div.head: THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
div.p: MR. DUNLOP AND HIS ACCUSERS.
FRENCH AND EGYPTIANS.

Mr. Dunlop, so the world, or rather M. Lambert and the three “Standards,” would have as believe inflicted severe injuries on the dignity of the ex-Director of the Khedivial Law School, compelling him as we pointed out to join in a conspiracy against the Minister of Education and to commit a variety of mean- neases—nasty tricks at which the Great Karamel blushes for shame. Indeed, if we are to believe the excellent jurist, Mr. Dunlop merits something more than dismissal ; indeed it would seem doubtful ir the gallotine— pardon we meant the gallows—were not too good an end for his misspent life. For all the treasures on earth, including those gathered from the subscriptions of the faithful to the three “Standards,” we would not stand in Mr. Dunlop's shoes.

The ex-Director of the Law School, knowing the strong national spirit of his compatriots, gives it to be clearly understood that one of the chief reasons of his resignation was the impossibility for a Frenchman to co-operate with a scheming and treacherous British chief. Any other action on his part would have com- promised the prestige of France. The children of perfidious Albion’ must be left to their national vices of treachery and lying. M. Lambert who combines the qualities of a diplomat and of a jurist, has in his letter, doubtless destined to be historic, appealed to the Chauvinism of a section of his countrymen. Paris was indignant when she heard of the disgraceful conduct of Mr. Dunlop and certain journals seemed about to call upon the Govern ment to denounce the “‘entente cordiale,” which benefited England and England only. Perbaps the most uncomfortably situated Frenchmen were the aediles of Paris. It is averred, by M. Lambert's friends, that they all but refused to go to London to empty numerous magnums and enlivened by the communicative warmth of the banquet to shed tears on the Lord Mayor's shirt tront.

Why did the ex-Director of the Law School, whose amour-propre was almost excessive, consent for months to be the Adviser's tool ! His case is a matter, not for the alienists as some declare, but for the onomatologists to quote in support of theirtheories. Who are the onomatologists | Persons who assert, with the confidence of the devotees of palmistry, that they can read a man's character, virtues, vices and all, in his Christian name or in one of his Christian names, ‘Paul,’ for example, any Paul you please, will be like the Apostle, energetic, quick tempered, a trifle hasty, and given to sudden changes of ideas, ‘conversions’ shall we say. Mr. Edonard Pan! Lambert cer tainly inspires us with some confidence in the ingenious hypothesis of M. de Rochetal. It certainly explains the ‘volte face,’ the contri bation to the leading journal of that ‘anti European’ movement which once caused Mr. Lambert such pain. As to the nature of Mr Lambeft's action—well —we can only emend Mme. Roland's dying apostrophe to Liberty and exclaim ‘Patriotism, what stupidities are committed in thy name.

Meanwhile the Director General of the Reli gious and Patriotic Monopoly has been swift to seize the chance offered by Mr. Lambert's misfortunes and aparring on Rosinante, rides full tilt not at the windmills which felled his illustrious predecessor but at Mr. Dunlop and perfidious Albion

Really the Pasha is rather an ungrateful young man—seeing that it is to the British Occupation that he owes his magnificent and enviable situation of exploiter of the Egyptian public which he fills with a rare competence. It is thanks tothe British Ocenpation too that he may one day become Khedive of Egypt or at least Resident of the Bahr el Ghazal

His press campaign violent as it is, is not enough, for a flourish of trampets in the three Standards anohnees a “Great Speech” at Alex andria. We are hippy to be able to give some of its most striking passages in advance. They ron as follows “Patriotism Parliament Pan Islamism Khedivial throne...... Perfi dious Albion end again “Patriotism Parliament” etc. The Great Karamel, musician in his inmost soul, has based his oratorical stile on the perambulant organ. At all events we may be sure that the Zizinia theatre will be full on Oct. 22, and that the imperial guard, recruited from the Sharia el Dawaween will applaud the delivery of every phrase of a carefully dictated and polished harangue, and will bear the hero in triamph on their shoulders at its close. Had we any influence with the bowab of the Palace of Don Quixote II, we should arge him to remind his master that the claqne deserve something for their pains, for is not this Ramadan! Perhaps they have received their reward. Do not the friends of “oor Director” whisper that he in » moment of expansion told an intimate friend under the seal of secrecy that the French are the friends of every oppressed race and showed their generosity by a little present of 30,000 francs The friend whispered and the public believed and marvelled—why | That is the question but if the tale be true we are sorry for M. Cailloux who with the budget nicely balanced sees his colleagne at the Quay d'Orsay handing over soms that might have relieved some of the victims of the floods of the Midi. But perhaps the Pasha’s friends are as imaginative as is his bodyguard of gladiatorial journalists and vebe- ment law students. It is more probable certainly
Meanwhile the Nationalist Press—or rather its more advanced sections—cheers M. Lam-

bert to the echo. The organs of the great Pontiff even discover that he has given abundant proofs of honesty and courgae. His romantic descriptions of Mr. Dunlop's conspi- racies are accepted without hestitation really, and if the ex-Director of the Law School had des- cribed the assassination of recalcitraunt students by Mr. Dunlop's orders in the groves of the Esbekieh garden, we believe that our excellent confrére the “Egyptian Standard” would have called upon the public to dig up the flower beds and look under the band-stand. And the worst of it all is that these 'advocates of educa- tion’ are doing Egypt all the harm in the world by attackingMr. Dunlop's personal character and by accepting M. Lambert's romances as if either had any bearing on the real question that is before the public "How can education be advanced in Egypt?" What Egypt requires is intelligence character. The country is not likely to obtain these blessing if its most intelligent sons spend their time in discussing the Advisor's mysterious villaninies, deride critics who seek to infuse a little common sense into their enthusiasm and devite themselves to personalities rather than constructive cri- ticism. Many of us Europeans are of opinion that educational progress in Egypt has not kept pace with the material develop: ment of the country but when we aré told that Europeans can know nothing of the real needs of the people and that Egyp- tians must beallowed te work out theirown salva- tion, we reply ‘la parole est à vous Messieurs’ and wait expectantly for edncational paténts from various newspaper offices, for practical suggestions and a constructive programme. What is the result—instead of giving us hints as to the improvement of the secondary school course “Al Lewa” with vast complacency cites the names of several local geniuses who once upon a time taught algebra or political economy through the medium of Arabic, instead of telling us what the Khedivial Law School must do to be saved : so to speak, the “Egyptian Standard” triumphantly informs us that Mr. Dunlop has a dreadful past, was a missionary and played upon the organ. Happily our contemporary for once in a way forgot the obvious and spared us the parallel of Nero fiddling while Rome burned and a painful picture of Mr. Dunlop pulling out a fresh stop as each Egyptian applicant was cast from the doors by his unwilling accomplice, Otherwise there is nothing for which we need be thankful ; personalities continue to descend like manna. Even the poets have been infected by the prevailing mania. Hafiz Ibrahim must now be playing at ‘boyaghi’, and after blacken- ing Lord Cromer's charcter and that of Mr. Dunlop puts a dash of blacking on Sir Eldon Gorst’s boots.
M. Lambert might have at least given some clearer indications of what, in his opinion, the Law School required.

But all he has to say on the subject amounts to this, that French is doomed as a go- vernmental language in Egypt and that the French School of Law has to be developed. Of the new situation created by the immense increase of the English side at the expense of the French in the secondary schools be has nothing to say worth onr attention. He has failed to point out the real difficulty —that the budding lawyers, members of the Parquet arrive at the Law School innocent of French with the result that they must learn a French legal system through the medium of English, a language practically never heard in the Mixed and useless in the Native Tribunals. We venture to suggest that the only real escape from the impasse is to increase the Arabic speaking staff, retaining such European professors as are masters of any particular branch of law and can lec ture in English or French but giving every pupil a chance of obtaining a good legal grounding in his mother-tongue. Once this system is in force it matters little whether the director of the Law School is English or French, or whether Mr. Dunlop was really a missionary or not. As for the question of discipline etc, we agree that it was too rigid, and we cannot help thinking that if Mr. Dunlop had left the Law School a little more independent matters would have gone better. Meanwhile the chief centre of higher education in Egypt seems destined to become the focus of the anti-European ideas which Mr. Lambert says that he deplores, and the public reads a new penny dreadful “Dunlop the Destroyer — or the Conrageous Professor and His Tyrant Chief.” Pranco-Bgyptian Publishing Co. Price 5 mil- liemes) and wonders whether it is all true.

div.head: COOK'S NILE TRIPS
div.p: Every year at the commencement of the season, for the first few sailings of Cook’s Nile steamers from Cairo to Assouan, a special reduction is made for residents of this country. Doubtless after the hot summer months which residents in Egypt have experienced, many Government officials and others will be glad to avail themselves of these sailings. The rates Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt) Ltd. are putting into operation this season “ate £25, instead of £50, for the tourist service by the sailings of Nov. 12th, 26th, and Deo. 8rd, ex-Cairo to Assouan, and £16, instead of £22. for the express service by the sailings ex-Cairo Nov. Ist, 8th, 15th, 22nd, 29th, Deo. 2nd & Tth. The journey to Assouan and back by tourist steamer occupies 20 days and the fare (which includes sightseeing ete.) is first rate in every respect. The express steamers occupy 19 days for the same journey, four days of which are spent at the Assouan and three days at Luxor
THE HOTEL-CASINO SAN STEFANO Will be open during winter Reduced Prices

div.head: FASHIONABLE WEDDING
div.p: On Saturday the 5th inst. at St. Paul's Church, Wimbledon Park, the marriage took place of Captain Charles Massie Blomfield, elder son of Rear-Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield of Alexandria, Egypt, and Miss Hirell Clarence, elder daughter of Mrs. Clarence of Castle Towers, Wimbledon Common. The service, which was fully choral, was con- ducted by the Rev. Charles Brooke, godfather of the bridegroom.

The bride, who was given away be her uncle, Mr. Porter Rhodes, was a gown of soft white satin, the corsage exquisitely embriodered in white and palest shade of pink. Her tulle viel over a wreath of organge blossoms was arranaged so taht it fell softly over the trained skirt. Her only ornament was a necklace of pearls.

The bridemaids, Miss Nora V. Clarence, sister of the bride, Miss. Susie Graves, cousin of the bridegroom, and Miss Isola Brotherton, cousin of the bride, wore cream crepe de chene gowns ornamented with gold tassels and key pattern, finely embriodered with gold thread. In their dark green satin hats hung a rich cavalier plume. The shoes were of dark Morocco, and the bouquets of roses of a deep shade of yellow were tied with green ribbon. The bridegroom's gifts to them were gold and white enamel bracelets with amethysts. Mr. Hugh Blomfield, brother of the bridegroom, acted as best man.
Following the ceremony a reception was held at Castle Towers, where the perfect weather permitted of the band of the Royal War- wickshire Regiment playing charming and suitable music in the grounds.
Later Captain and Mrs. Blomfield left for the Italian lakes, the bride wearing a gown of cherry-coloured cloth, the daintily-cut bolero covering a corsage of lovely lace.
Among the numerous and handsome presents we may mention the following :--

From the bridegroom to the bride, diamond and enamel pendant with gold chain: from the bride's mother to the bride, diamond neck lace ; Adimiral Sir R. Massie and Lady Blom- field, handsomely-fitted cantéen ; officers of ment, silver salver;Derd and Lady George Seymour silver t; Admiral Sir Ri- chard and Lady Poore, breakfast service and tray ; Admiral Northland, cheque; Sir St. Vincent and Lady Hammick, tea table; Mr. Hugh Blomfield, orstich-feather and tortoise- shell fan and Sudanese silver embossed cigar- ette box. Mra Geddes, Mra. Stewart Geddes, Miss Geddes, and Mr. Geddes handsome silver centre-picoe and silver flower-vases ; the Lady Monteagle, fish slice; Mr. Rhodes pearl studs, silver tea-service, and cheque; Archdeacon and Mrs. Ward cooper stampbox; Sir Henry Bulwer aneroid barometer; Mr. Lionel San- dars nest of hand-painted tables; Mr. and Mrs. A.P. Graves, pearl creséent ‘brooch and silver soupladle; Mr. and Mrs. Moss, silver Specimen vases ; General Sir Cecil and Lady Kast, black jack jug, silver mounted; Miss N. Clarence, cakestand ; Mr. and Mra. Preston, compasses ; Mr. Arderne Clarence, gold but tons and entrée dishes ; Miss Powys, miniatare of the late Lord Bishop of Limerick ; Mr. C.L. and Mr. R.W. Graves, Irish lace; Dixon Bey and Miss Dixon tall bonbon silver dishes ; Mrs. Pelton Perl travelling-inkpot ; Miss Vansommer, “Egypt” by Talbot-Kelly ; Mrs. Barker, travelling clock ; Mr. and Mrs. Ben- well Rees, hammered silver inkpot ; Mr. and Mrs. P. Foster, silver cigarette box ; etc.

div.head: RECORD OF EARTHQUAKE.
div.p: HELOUAN SEISMOGRAPH DISTURBANCE.

Yesterday morning at six o'clock a consider- able disturbanoe, indicating an earthquake, was registered by the seismograph at the Helouan observatory. The distaneefrom the observatory at which the earthquake is estinrated to have occurred is 1,500 kilometres.

div.head: EGYPT'S ROYAL VISITOR.
div.p: DEPARTURE FROM SUEZ
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Suez, Tuesday
The Norddeutscher Lloyd 8.8 “Sachsen” sailed eastwards from Suez at daybreak this morning with the King of Siam aboard.

div.head: KAMEL AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The demonstration at the Bab-el-Ghedid terminus on the occasion of the arrival of Mustapha Pasha Kamel at Alexandria yester- day wasa deplorable tailure. Not a single native ofany importance put in an appearance and only a few small Arab youths greeted him.

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT
div.p: One of the Government administrations, which will be chiefly affected by the new policy of “Egypt for the Egyptians” is the Irrigation Service. Hitherto the posts of In spectors of Circle, have been in English hands, but Wel Gnlefetand What flies posts are in future to be thrown open to natives.

div.head: Cheap GAs from Common Fuels
div.p: for Engines, Manufacturing, Furances, Pump ing, Irrigation, Incandescents Lighting and Generation of Electricity. Lane's Producers are available for Land, River or Ocean Service. Agents required. Address Howard Lane, 125 Edmund Street, Birmingham, England

It has been stated that Sir Eldon Gorst would have the same precedence as Lord Cromer enjoyed as Doyen of the Diplomatic Crops. But Lord Cromer only held this posi- tion by right of seniority as the senior Diplo- matic Agent, and not as the representative of the Occupying Power. Sir Eldon Gorst will not take precedence of the other members of the Corps and will consequently only by seniority.
A rumour has been current in Alexandria this morning that the Sirdar had broken his leg, but we are glad to learn that there is not the lightest foundation for such a report
Mr. Mitchell Innes, Under Secretary of State for Finance, has disposed of his house and furniture at Ghizeh.
Hussdein Rushdi Pasha has left for for Paris, where his wife is about to undergo an operation
Miralai Owen Bey has returned from Eng- land to Cairo
Mr. Maspero, Director of the Service of Antiquities, was among the passengers who arrived by the French mail boat this morning
Piot Bey and Mrs. Piot returned to Alexan- dria this morning by the M.M. S.S "Orenique"
Among other passengers who arrived this morning by the "Orenique" were Castelli Bey, Mr. Leblanc, Mr. Roland Jackson, Misses Ruffer, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Bey, and Miss Reynolds.

The engagement is announced of Mr. Hugh Massie Blomfield, of the Egyptian Civil Ser- vice, younger son of Rear-Admiral Sir Massie and the Lady Blomfield of Port Hosue, Alex- andria, to Marget Alice only daughter of the late Mr. Stewart Geddes, of Bloemfontein, South Africa and Mrs. Stewart Geddes, and grand-duaghter of the late Mr. James Geddes of Linden Forquay. Miss Geddes is a grad daughter of the late Mr. Trutae, Sub-Commis- sioner and Resident Magistrate of the late Orange Free State, and a cousin of the late Sir John Brand, the well-known Presidet of the Orange Free State
Among the passengers who arrived yester- day by the S.S "Hohenzollern" were Mr. Lang Anderson and Miss. Hila Lang Ander- son, who are now at teh Blue House, Schultz, Ramleh
Mr. Horace C. Back has returned to Cairo from England, where he spent an enjoyable three months' holiday

Mr. Wild, Manager of the Savoy Hotel, Cairo returned from Europe yesterday with his family by the S.S "Semiramis". He is leaving the Hotel Casino San Stefano to-day for Cairo. Mr. Wild has passed the greater part of the summer at his hotal in Zurich, Switzerland (the Hotel National) and has been doing very well, having had a most excellent season. He is now going to Cairo to push the final work to open the Savoy Hotel in Cairo as soon possible.
Mr. Wollaston has done good work as Examiner in Persian at the Royal Staff College, Sandhurst, and in superintending the transla- tion of Oriental inscriptions in the South Kensington Museum

Mr. Arthar Naylor Wollaston, C. I. E, Registrar and Superintendent of Records at the India Office, whose retirement is announced, is a distinguished Oriental scholar. He has published serveral important works on eastern subjects, including a translation of the "Anvari- Suhaili, or Fables of Bidpai" and an English- Persian dictionary. He is author of "Half hours with Mahommed" and "The Sword of Islam.”

div.head: MILITARY NOTES.
div.p: Lieutenant C.E. Vickery, D.S.O., Royal Artillery, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi.
Bimbashi M.J. Hamilton, Bahr el Ghazal District, having completed his term of service, is struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army.
The Sirdar will inspect the 2nd Battalion, Egyptian Aemt, at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning at Abdin, Cairo
The last detachment of the Royal Dublin Fussiliers left Alexandria this morning at a quater to five for Cario en route to Khartoum

div.head: TELEGRAPH STAFF'S PETITION.
div.p: The petition presented to the Telegraph authorities, by their employes, through perhaps going rather wide of the mark in places, as when it is complaine that promotion is only granted to a favoured few, appears to be reason- able enough in its demand for a month's pay as bonus. The Department is a hard working one, and we hope that the Authorities will see their way clear to marking their appreciation of the fact by granting the request. Promotio, by the way, is granted to the favoured few, those few who by reason of their ability have proved themselves worthy to merit it.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: A. S. C.
OCTOBER SKYE MEETING.
The following are the entries closed yes- terday :-

MAIDEN PONY PLATE - Khalil Pasha Khayat's Souhab, Mr. G. L Sursock Bye's Atril, Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's Gawsber, Mr. Ed. Bustros' Bagdad and Pusay, Mr. A. J. Michaelide's Pelops, Ibrahim Bey Cherif's Kaboul

Maiden HRSE PLATE - H.H Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's Hilal and Nasri, Khalil Pasha Khayat's Latiff II;Ibrahim Bey Cherif's Gouman, Mr. G. L. Sursock's Bey Mirator, Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's Geylin Mr. C. G. Pilavachi's Ginger, Capt. Leigh's Messond and Douglas.
MAHMOUDIEH PLATE - Mr. A. M. Johnson's Mleyhan, Baron J. E. de Mensace's Petrone, Ibrahim Bey Cherif's Kouzou and Bull Dog, Mr. A. J. Sursock's Karro

ABOUKIR STAKES - H.H. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's Kahraman, Khalil Pasha Khayat's Doughan and Khadrouf, Hassan Bey Kheir el Bin's Abou Gebel, Mr. Ed. Bustro's Mahboub, Ibrahim Bey Cherif's KAra Aslan, Mr. A. J. Sursock's Alarm
THE NILE PLATE - Khalil Pasha Khayat's Khadrouf, Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's Lahek, BAron J.E. de Menasce's Rainbow and Radium. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's Ghari and Midado

ONDURMAN PLATE- H.H. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's Hital, Khalil Pasha Khayat's Douglas and Tehaene, Hassan Bey Khefr el Din's Abon Gebel, Baron J.E. de Menasce's Faineant, Mr. Ed. Bustros MAshbonb Gladiator, Ibrahim Bey CHerif's Valentine and Shendi, Mr. A. T. Sursock's Mercury

div.head: BRITISH RIFILE CLUB (ALEX.)
div.p: The final shoot for the Champion Cups will take place on Saturday next, 26th inst., when a shooting-bag and two extra spoons will also be competed for, concurrently with the shoot- ing fro the cups. Members who do not desire to enter for the shooting-bag may be excluded from that event on making a declaration to that effect before commencement of the competition

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB
div.p: REGATTA
The handicap and times of starting for to- morrow's regatta are the same as last week. Class I and Rating - Course E Class II - Course Q

div.head: THE SAINT ANDREW FOOTBALL CLUB
div.p: The fifth annual general meeting of the above Club was held in the Committee Room of the British club, kindly granted for the occassion, on Thursday evening last, the Pre- sident of the club, Rev. H.P. Reid, occuppyin the chair. The chairman in the course of his remarks wished the club all success in the new season. The secretary reported on the general working of the club and the prospects for the new season, and anticipated that the team would give a good amount of itself in all fixtures. The team will play in new colours this season, these being Royal Blue Jerseys and white knickers. The finncial position of the club was shown to be a sound one, and with increased memebership it is hoped to be able to lease a suitable area of land for the exclusive use of the club. Office bearers were elected for the new season and some general business discussed. The meeting closed with a vote of thanks to the chairman.

The new officers thereafter met in committee when it was arranged to commerce the season with a test game on Saturday next, 26th inst. between two elevens of the club's playing members. The Head Master of the Victoria College has kindly granted the use of the College football ground for this match. A good game should be witnessed

div.head: LORD CROMER'S MEMORIAL
div.p: Subscriptions are now being invited for the memorial to Lord Cromer's life-work in Egypt which is to take the form of the continuation and extension of Lady Cromer's dispensaries for children. Donations to the fund will be graetfully recieved by the Hon. Treausrer, the Governor of the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo , where any subscriber can see the sub- scribtion list

div.head: Steamer Movements
div.p: The Moss liner "menes" sailed from Liver- pool on Staurday last, and is due here about the 2nd prox. with passangers, mails, and general cargo.
The Hilerman liner "Sardinia" sailed from Malta last evening for Tripelo (Barlary) and Alexandria

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.
